message_1:
A delivery person needs to visit six different locations in a city. The distances between each location are given in the table below. What is the shortest possible total distance the delivery person can travel to visit all six locations? 

|   | A   | B   | C   | D   | E   | F   |
|---|---|---|---|---|---|---|
| A | - | 9 | 6 | 7 | 5 | 8 |
| B | 9 | - | 5 | 3 | 3 | 9 |
| C | 6 | 5 | - | 7 | 8 | 2 |
| D | 7 | 3 | 7 | - | 5 | 4 |
| E | 5 | 3 | 8 | 5 | - | 2 |
| F | 8 | 9 | 2 | 4 | 2 | - |
message_2:
To find the shortest possible total distance, we can use the traveling salesman problem approach. We will find the shortest path that visits each location exactly once and returns to the starting location.

We can start by finding the shortest path from each location to any other location:

1. From A: A -> E (5), A -> C (6), A -> D (7)
2. From B: B -> E (3), B -> D (3), B -> C (5)
3. From C: C -> F (2), C -> B (5), C -> A (6)
4. From D: D -> B (3), D -> F (4), D -> E (5)
5. From E: E -> F (2), E -> B (3), E -> D (5)
6. From F: F -> C (2), F -> E (2), F -> D (4)

Now, we can try to find the shortest path that visits each location exactly once:

1. A -> E (5) -> F (2) -> C (2) -> B (5) -> D (3) -> A (7) = 24
2. A -> C (6) -> F (2) -> E (2) -> B (3) -> D (3) -> A (7) = 23
3. A -> D (7) -> B (3) -> E (3) -> F (2) -> C (2) -> A (6) = 23

The shortest possible total distance the delivery person can travel to visit all six locations is 23 units.
